The
Trænadjupet and Storegga slide areas (Fig. 1, Tables 2 and 3) are
characterized by the modest sedimentation rates (less than
1 m/kyr) during interglacials alternated with signiﬁcantly higher
sedimentation rates (several tens of meters per kyr) at the end of
each glacial period.
3. Stratigraphy (after Solheim et al., 2005a) of mid-Norwegian submarine slides shows 100 kyr cyclic instability during the last 500 ka (see Fig.

Rapid overloading of
ﬁne-grained
sediments could generate excess pore pressure
depending on permeability and water content in the sediment.

A high excess
pore pressure developing in the soil during consolidation will
impede the natural increase of effective stress with sediment
burial.

When the sediment is
initially fully consolidated (i.e. complete dissipation of excess pore
pressure), a cyclic loading such as earthquake ground motion or gas
accumulation can generate excess pore pressure in the sediment
pores.

The undrained shear strength is only affected by excess pore
pressure generation if liquefaction occurs, or by cyclic loading
leading to a possible degradation of shear strength.

head: the excess pore pressure
tail: more or less the initial vertical effective stress

provenance.sentence:
Liquefaction means that the excess pore pressure in sandy sedi-
ments equals more or less the initial vertical effective stress
(vertical effective stress becoming zero) and thus the sediment
shear strength approaches null values (in other words, the sedi-
ment behaves as a liquid).

Liquefaction means that the excess pore pressure in sandy sedi-
ments equals more or less the initial vertical effective stress
(vertical effective stress becoming zero) and thus the sediment
shear strength approaches null values (in other words, the sedi-
ment behaves as a liquid).

Additionally, extensive polygonal faulting, a non-tectonic
class of faults related to sediment contraction and ﬂuid expulsion,
has affected the underlying formation, and is thought to control
ﬂuid ﬂow on a regional scale (Bu¨ nz et al., 2003; Bryn et al., 2005a).

Vogt and Jung (2002) and Mienert et al. (2005) propose a situ-
ation in which submarine slopes of the Norwegian margin receive
preconditions to slope failure due to methane hydrate dissociation.

Modelling illustrated that the area of critical hydrate
stability changes along the mid-Norwegian margin correspond
remarkably well with the location of the Storegga Headwall, as
inferred from seismic reﬂection proﬁles (Mienert et al., 2005), and
hence, hydrate dissociation could precondition secondary slope
failures along the upper slope in the retrogressive slide develop-
ment of the Storegga landslide (McIver, 1982; Mienert et al., 2002;
Vogt and Jung, 2002; Mienert et al., 2005).

(1) Under triaxial compression tests on samples from the Træ-
nadjupet Slide area, the contourite drift sediments exhibit
a contractant behaviour resulting in the development of shear
bands (Laberg et al., 2003) which correspond to strain

This behaviour is characteristic of low pre-
shear density and suggests that excess pore pressure genera-
tion could initiate shear bands and thus failure in the sediment.

The retro-
gressive slide model proposed by Kvalstad et al. (2002, 2005a,b)
requires the initial removal of sediment from the toe of the slope.

Okamoto et al. (2004) identiﬁed two recent
landslides in Norway (in quick clay deposits) where secondary and
tertiary creep stages were observed before the failure.

This
suggests that, locally, slope angle does not signiﬁcantly inﬂuence the
occurrence of large-scale sliding on glaciated margins.

Nielsen
and van Weering (1998) also concluded that instability along the
northeastern Faeroes margin might be triggered by rapid steepening
of the slope angle.

Faults induced by
tectonics can play a role as a trigger mechanism as proposed by
Reeder et al. (2000) for the Herodotus Basin mega-turbidite.

On the marginal slopes of the
eastern Mediterranean Seas, Lykoussis et al. (2003) observed that
slope instabilities could be induced by ground acceleration.

Perissoratis and Papadopoulos (1999) report that a large
mass movement in the southwestern part of the Amorgos basin
(south of the Aegean sea) has been triggered by one (or both) July
1956 seismic events (M ¼ 7:5 main shock and M ¼ 7:2 aftershock,
13 min later), with the epicentre located in the immediate vicinity
of the headwall scarp (less than 10 km off target).

Here, a combination of
trigger and pre-conditioning factors may have promoted instability
of the slope, which includes oversteepening, reduction of shear
strength along the fault plane, and differential compaction and
faulting associated with a deep-rooted inactive volcanic dome.

Trincardi and Argnani (1990) also mention that an intense volca-
notectonic
activity as
triggering
mechanism
combined
with
a decollement surface (precondition to failure) could explain the
observed Gela Slide (Table 2, Fig. 1).

Embankment increased the loading on shallower as well as deeper
sediments leading to the failure with (decreasing soil resistance) or
without (increasing loading) excess pore pressure development.

However, during sea-
level lowstands large portions of the shelf areas were exposed, and
sediment transport from rivers reached the shelf edge and upper
slope resulting in sand deposition.

Thus, during falling stages of sea
level (or low sea level), slope failures and increased canyon inci-
sions dominate with large portions of the sediments being trans-
ported to the deep basin (Berne´ et al., 2004).

On glaciated margins during glacial times, the
stability of submarine gas hydrates increased because cold bottom
water masses present on the upper slope offsets the effect of
pressure drop (Fig. 4).

Sediment destabilization is most likely
controlled by sediment supply, which in turn causes steeper slope

Vertical tectonic movements due
to the decay of ice sheets (rising sea level) cause an increase in
seismic activity on glaciated margins (Bungum et al., 2005).

Thus,
times of intense isostatic rebound may invoke high magnitude
earthquakes on NE-Atlantic passive margins, similar in magnitude
to today’s active Mediterranean margins.

In contrast, non-glaciated margins were
continuously submerged by warmer waters and should have
experienced more stable gas hydrates due to sea level rise.

For the Agadir
Canyon system (Ercilla et al., 2003), one large turbidity current
feeds the Agadir Basin every 30 kyr (Weaver et al., 2000).

When
compared with submarine slides on the formerly glaciated mid-
Norwegian margin where one mega-slide occurred approximately
every 100 kyr (Solheim et al., 2005a), the frequency of mega events
is higher on non-glaciated margins.

There is evidence that earthquakes with amplitudes similar to
active eastern Mediterranean margins seismicity concentrated on
formerly glaciated margins during peak deglaciation periods.

In
addition, sedimentation rates on glaciated margins show high and
rapid depositions during glacial and deglaciation times.

Rivers transported
sandy sediments directly to the shelf edge and upper slope creating
unstable slope conditions.

The latter occurred during a low sea level
when erosion by rivers caused major canyon incisions and mass
movements on the upper slope as identiﬁed in the western Medi-
terranean (e.g. Droz et al., 2001).

Large-scale slides dominate
north of 62N whereas megaturbidites and debris ﬂows are mainly
observed south of 35N. A broad range of mass wasting processes
are observed in the Mediterranean sea whereas they are rather
scarce between 35N and 52N on the Atlantic margin.

(2) On glaciated margins (low slope angle), submarine slides are
closely related to the extent of ice sheets and the location of con-
tourites on continental slopes; north of 62N, mega-scale sliding is
preponderant during sea level rise from glacial to interglacial times
whereas on non-glaciated margins (high slope angle), mega-
turbidites and debris ﬂows occur predominantly during low sea
level when rivers transported their sediment load directly to the
shelf edge and coastal upwelling was limited to the upper slope.

A sequence stratigraphic framework includes genetic units that result from the interplay of accommodation and sedimentation 
(i.e., forced regressive, lowstand and highstand normal regressive, and transgressive), which are bounded by “sequence strati-
graphic” surfaces.

During a stillstand of base level (not shown), the shoreline may undergo sediment-driven progradation (normal regression, where the topset is re-
placed by toplap), erosional transgression, or no movement at all.

head:
The seismic and large-scale outcrop 
data

provenance.sentence:
The seismic and large-scale outcrop 
data provide continuous subsurface and surface information respectively.

For example, 
onshore “mature” petroleum basins may offer the entire range 
of data sets, whereas offshore “frontier” basins may initially be 
interpreted in stratigraphic terms only through the analysis of 
seismic data.

mic data provide continuous coverage of relatively large areas 
at the expense of vertical resolution, whereas outcrops, core and 
well logs may provide the opportunity for more detailed stud-
ies in particular locations but within the context of a sparse and 
discontinuous data base.

head:
more re-
cent multichannel seismic data

provenance.sentence:
In the early days of seismic stratigraphy, the verti-
cal seismic resolution was 20–30 m or more, whereas more re-
cent multichannel seismic data have 5 m of vertical resolution 
or less, depending on the depth of investigation.

The same problem affects the interpretation 
of outcrops which expose “massive” beds (no grading).

The selection of the option that makes most 
geological sense is based on a facies model of deltaic progradation which 
indicates that clinoforms downlap the maximum flooding surface in a 
basinward (i.e., easterly) direction (C).

For example, pinpointing the surface that is interpreted to 
mark the time of maximum shoreline transgression along a dep-
ositional-dip transect (i.e., a “maximum flooding surface”) within 
a condensed section of meters or tens of meters of shale may in-
volve a margin of error equivalent to the thickness of the con-
densed section.

head: Examples
tail:
maximum flooding and maxi-
mum regressive surfaces

provenance.sentence:
Examples include maximum flooding and maxi-
mum regressive surfaces in siliciclastic shallow-water settings, 
interpreted at the top of fining-upward and coarsening-upward 
trends respectively.

In this case, the clinoforms interpreted in Figure 9C comply 
with a model which predicts that clinoforms downlap the maxi-
mum flooding surface in a basinward direction.

The concept of “base level” delin-
eates a dynamic surface of balance between erosion and deposi-
tion.

Equivalent definitions place this equilibrium surface at the 
lowest level of continental erosion, at the lowest point on a flu-
vial profile, or at the highest level up to which a sedimentary suc-
cession can be built (Twenhofel, 1939; Sloss, 1962).

It has been sug-
gested that these two concepts can be amalgamated into the con-
cept of “stratigraphic base level” that marks the surface of equi-
librium between sedimentation and erosion in all depositional 
settings (Cross and Lessenger, 1998).

The erosion that generates transgressive ravinement surfaces may be triggered by 
waves or tides (hence the usage of plural).

The erosion that generates transgressive ravinement surfaces may be triggered by 
waves or tides (hence the usage of plural).

The latter type of architecture defines “forced 
regressive” deposits (Posamentier et al., 1992; Posamentier and 
Morris, 2000), and the surface that bounds them at the base is 
identified on the basis of stratal stacking patterns and inferred to 
correlate in time with the onset-of-base-level-fall “event.”

Transgressions occur 
when the rates of base-level rise outpace the sedimentation rates.

In both cases progradation is 
driven by sediment supply: sedimentation rates outpace the rates of base-level rise at the shoreline.

In both cases progradation is 
driven by sediment supply: sedimentation rates outpace the rates of base-level rise at the shoreline.

These depositional trends reflect the pattern of change in 
the rates of creation of accommodation during the two types of normal regression (Figure 16).

The boundary between the transgressive and highstand systems tracts is 
represented by the maximum flooding surface (downlap surface).

In this case, a larger scale sequence may ex-
clude a transgressive systems tract, but the higher frequency 
cycles that are nested within this sequence will include trans-
gressive deposits (i.e., lower rank transgressive systems tracts).
Erosion may obliterate the record of various systems tracts.

Sediment starvation during rapid 
base-level rise may prevent the accumulation or preservation of 
offshore transgressive facies.

“Depositional” sequences are bounded by subaerial un-
conformities and their marine correlative conformities (Figure 
24).

head:
maximum regres-
sive or maximum flooding surfaces

provenance.sentence:
Depositional sequences are not bounded by maximum regres-
sive or maximum flooding surfaces, the timings of which are 
offset relative to the timing of subaerial unconformities (Figure 
24).

Regardless of 
systems-tract terminology and the choice of correlative confor-
mities, all depositional sequence models acknowledge the im-
portance of separating forced regressive, normal regressive 
(lowstand and highstand) and transgressive deposits as distinct 
genetic units.

The “genetic stratigraphic” sequence model (Galloway, 1989) 
uses maximum flooding surfaces as sequence boundaries (Fig-
ures 4, 23, & 24).

head: they
tail:
a sin-
gle, through-going physical surface

provenance.sentence:
In analyses that involve both nonmarine and marine systems, 
it is required that the two segments of the “sequence boundary” 
be age-equivalent at the coastline, so that they always form a sin-
gle, through-going physical surface from the fluvial to the ma-
rine portion of the basin.

It has also been proposed 
that the term “parasequence” be expanded to include all re-
gionally significant meter-scale cycles, whether or not they are 
bounded by flooding surfaces (Spence and Tucker, 2007).

Forced regressive 
deposits display diagnostic progradational and downstepping 
stacking patterns (Figures 2 & 7).

Normal regres-
sions occur where sedimentation rates outpace the rates of new 
accommodation added due to base-level rise at the shoreline.

Normal regres-
sive deposits display a combination of progradational and ag-
gradational depositional trends (Figures 2, 7, & 18).

Where offlap is not preserved, 
this surface marks the change from an increase (upstepping) to a 
decrease (downstepping) in the elevation of coastal facies.

Alternative terms include the “basal surface 
of forced regression” (Hunt and Tucker, 1992).

Where offlap is not preserved, 
this surface marks the change from a decrease (downstepping) to 
an increase (upstepping) in the elevation of coastal facies.

Alternative terms include: transgressive surface (Posamentier 
and Vail, 1988); top of lowstand surface (Vail et al., 1991); initial 
transgressive surface (Nummedal et al., 1993); conformable trans-
gressive surface (Embry, 1995); surface of maximum regression 
(Helland-Hansen and Gjelberg, 1994; Mellere and Steel, 1995); 
maximum progradation surface (Emery and Myers, 1996).

Along strike, the 
maximum flooding surface may record a higher degree of dia-
chroneity, depending on the variations in sediment supply and 
subsidence rates.

Alternative terms include the “transgressive 
surface of erosion” (Posamentier and Vail, 1988).

These surfaces 
are commonly also flooding surfaces.

The criteria that can be used to identify each sequence strati-
graphic surface include: the conformable versus unconformable 
nature of the contact; the depositional systems below and above 
the contact; the depositional trends below and above the contact; 
the types of substrate-controlled ichnofacies associated with the 
contact; and stratal terminations associated with the contact (see 
Figure 4.9 in Catuneanu, 2006, for a recent review of criteria).

A seismic clinoform 
may represent a single sequence stratigraphic surface, such as a 
maximum regressive surface or a correlative conformity, within 
a large-scale stratigraphic framework.

Lower rank surfaces 
superimposed on higher rank ones do not change the strati-
graphic significance of the latter within the broader frame-
work.

head:
a third-order transgres-
sive ravinement surface

provenance.sentence:
For example, a second-order subaerial unconformity that 
is overlain by the fluvial topset of a second-order lowstand sys-
tems tract may be reworked in part by a third-order transgres-
sive ravinement surface.
Farther upstream, the maximum regressive surface may eventually onlap the subaerial unconformity.

The most straightforward application of the sequence strati-
graphic method is afforded by areas adjacent to the coastline (in 
particular, coastal to shallow-water settings), where all seven 
surfaces of sequence stratigraphy may form (Figure 17).

In this example, gradationally-based shoreface deposits indicate normal regression (highstand to the left; lowstand to the right), whereas sharp-
based shoreface deposits are diagnostic for forced regression.

Kolla, 2003; Catuneanu, 2006): (1) mudflow deposits, dominated by lobes; (2) high-density turbidites, dominated by frontal splays; (3) low-density tur-
bidites, dominated by leveed channels.

Abbrevia-
tions: HNR — highstand normal regressive deposits; FR — forced regressive deposits; LNR — lowstand normal regressive deposits; T — transgres-
sive deposits; CC* — correlative conformity sensu Posamentier and Allen (1999); CC** — correlative conformity sensu Hunt and Tucker (1992); MRS 
— maximum regressive surface; MFS — maximum flooding surface.

Abbrevia-
tions: HNR — highstand normal regressive deposits; FR — forced regressive deposits; LNR — lowstand normal regressive deposits; T — transgres-
sive deposits; CC* — correlative conformity sensu Posamentier and Allen (1999); CC** — correlative conformity sensu Hunt and Tucker (1992); MRS 
— maximum regressive surface; MFS — maximum flooding surface.

tions: HNR — highstand normal regressive deposits; FR — forced regressive deposits; LNR — lowstand normal regressive deposits; T — transgres-
sive deposits; CC* — correlative conformity sensu Posamentier and Allen (1999); CC** — correlative conformity sensu Hunt and Tucker (1992); MRS 
— maximum regressive surface; MFS — maximum flooding surface.

The formation of subaerial unconformities in upstream-con-
trolled fluvial settings may be attributed to stages of increased 
fluvial energy, which may be triggered by tectonic or climatic 
forcing.

A — mudflow deposits (chaotic internal facies): early stage of forced regres-
sion; B — turbidity-flow frontal splay (well-defined parallel reflections): late stage of forced regression; C — leveed channel and overbank facies (high-
amplitude reflections associated with the sandy channel fill and weak reflections/transparent facies associated with the finer grained overbank depos-
its): lowstand normal regressive and early transgressive deposits; D — mudflow deposits (chaotic internal facies): late transgressive deposits.

Arguably, sequence stratigra-
phy is easiest to apply in these environments, where the shifts 
in depositional trends are more evident and all sequence strati-
graphic surfaces may form (Figure 17).

These changes control sediment 
supply (both volume and grain size) to the deep-water setting 
(see Catuneanu, 2006, for a full discussion).

However, both the 
volume and the grain size of the sediment that is delivered to 
the deep-water setting may also be modified by the size and the 
energy of the rivers that bring sediment to the coastline, as well 
as by the width of the continental shelf.

Additional controls may include changes in sediment supply 
and dispersal patterns, autocyclic processes of fan switching, 
unpredictable changes in energy flux such as the ones caused by 
hurricanes, and local accommodation changes caused by under-
lying salt, shale or basement tectonics that create localized sub-
basins (Underhill, 1991; Galloway, 2001b, 2004; Sinclair and To-
masso, 2002; Posamentier and Kolla, 2003).

Carbonate stratigraphic sections are thus 
similarly punctuated by key bounding surfaces that include sub-
aerial unconformities, correlative conformities, maximum flood-
ing surfaces, flooding surfaces, maximum regressive surfaces, re-
gressive surfaces of marine erosion, and transgressive ravinement 
surfaces (Figure 32).

Architecture of facies, genetic units (systems tracts) and sequence stratigraphic surfaces of a Late Devonian reef system that developed on a 
gently sloping, epicontinental ramp (Alexandra Formation, Western Canada Sedimentary Basin; modified from MacNeil and Jones, 2006).

A 
platform that had been the site of carbonate production during 
periods of base-level rise may now no longer generate carbonate 
sediment.

Provided the build-
up margins are not too deep or steep for carbonate production, 
these marginal areas may become the sites of sediment accumula-
tion as a forced regressive deposit (e.g., MacNeil and Jones, 2006; 
Figure 32).

The 
surface that underlies the forced regressive deposits is the correl-
ative conformity sensu Posamentier and Allen (1999), and may be 
replaced in part by the regressive surface of marine erosion.

The 
surface that overlies the forced regressive deposits is the correl-
ative conformity sensu Hunt and Tucker (1992) (Figure 32).

Strasser et al. (2006) illustrated how carbonate sedimentary 
cycles record repetitive changes (e.g., in stacking pattern, facies, 
biological and geochemical composition), often driven by peri-
odic changes in accommodation.

provenance.sentence:

both nonmarine and marine settings, it is required that the two 
portions of the “sequence boundary” be age-equivalent at the 
coastline, so that they always form a single through-going phys-

head: The geomorphic, tectonic and dynamic settings

provenance.sentence:
The geomorphic, tectonic and dynamic settings have a strong 
influence on the way in which the changes in accommodation 
are expressed or preserved.

Abstract: Gravity tectonics affects the entire marine sedimentary sequence of the Foz do Amazonas basin,
including the topmost Amazon Fan.

head:
the sedimentary
loading and bathymetric slope

provenance.sentence:
During the various stages of the margin’s evolution, the sedimentary
loading and bathymetric slope induced the formation of a linked extensional–compressional system in which
gravitational fold-and-thrust belts form signiﬁcant structural features on the continental slope.

Seismic analysis
carried out in this study shows that sea-ﬂoor relief created along these thrust belts can trigger recurrent mass-
transport deposits in the upper–middle Amazon Fan, suggesting a long-lasting linkage between gravity
tectonics and mass-transport processes throughout the sedimentary evolution of the Amazon Fan.

Both the basin and its topmost fan stratigraphic succes-
sions (c. 10 Ma) have been affected by features of gravitational
collapse at different time and space scales (Fig. 1).

The entire marine sequence of the basin is deformed by an
upslope set of extensional faults and downslope gravitational
fold-and-thrust belts considered to root into basal weak levels
(e.g. Silva et al. 1999; Zala´n 2005).

Although these structures
affect large areas of the basin, they are not well discussed in the
scientiﬁc literature.

The fan
was built primarily by huge volumes of terrigenous sediments
carried out to the sea by the Amazon River (Figueiredo et al.
2007), but we lack chronostratigraphic details about the entire
fan series, as most of the studies on the Amazon Fan have
focused on the Quaternary fan section, involving deposition of
channel–levee systems and mass-transport deposits (e.g. Damuth
& Embley 1981;

The Foz do Amazonas basin covers an area of about 268
000 km2, extending to c. 3000 m water depth, located on the
northwestern part of the Brazilian Equatorial margin (Figueiredo
et al. 2007).

Previous studies on gravity tectonics in the Foz do
Amazonas basin

The upper 500–800 m of the Amazon Fan consists of over-
lapping channel–levee systems (100–200 m thick) grouped into
major levee complexes that were formed by periodic channel
avulsions during sea-level lowstands (Damuth et al. 1988; Lopez
2001).

Piper et
al. (1997a) cited gravity tectonics (referred to as ‘shale diapirs’)
as another possible cause of mass-transport processes in the
Amazon Fan but did not explore this hypothesis.

We present below the results of 2D seismic analyses to evaluate
how gravity tectonics evolves and how it affects sedimentation in
the Foz do Amazonas basin.

Structural styles of gravity tectonics in the Foz do
Amazonas basin

head:
both
seaward- and landward-dipping listric normal faults

provenance.sentence:
The updip extensional domain, located between the mid-
continental shelf and the upper slope, is characterized by both
seaward- and landward-dipping listric normal faults with strike
orientation in a general NW–SE direction, stratigraphic wedges
and rollover anticlines, as well as minor antithetic planar normal
faults (Figs 1 and 2a, b).

On the continental shelf, proximal normal faults are mostly
now inactive, whereas closer to the shelf break and upper slope,
listric faults can reach the sea ﬂoor and form fault scarps as high
as 150–180 m (Figs 2a, b and 3a).

These faults affect the entire overlying sedimentary package,
leading to the formation of several ponded basins (piggy-back
basins) (Figs 2c, d and 3a).

However, structural analyses and bathymetric data suggest
that structural compartments are linked by relay ramps along
which the Amazon canyon is structurally controlled, until c.
1400 m water depth, beyond which the canyon decreases its
average 600 m vertical relief and changes into channel–levee
systems.

The translational domain connects the upslope extension to the
downslope compression in a relatively undisturbed mode, across
areas up to 50–60 km wide.

Deformation
is also illustrated by the antithetic growth normal faults that
occur as local extensional structures in the transitional zone.

Active normal growth faults form the
upslope boundaries of maximum sedimentary thickness of both
depocentres (Fig. 4).

Active thrust faults can reach the sea ﬂoor
and have a major bathymetric impact on the upper submarine
fan, forming fault scarps up to 500 m high.

Active thrust faults can reach the sea ﬂoor
and have a major bathymetric impact on the upper submarine
fan, forming fault scarps up to 500 m high.

The
associated structural style is variable along strike, with the
prevalence of zones of sea-ﬂoor structural uplift as a result of
folding and/or faulting (Fig. 5a); locally, active thrust faults can
reach the sea ﬂoor, forming fault-related scarps up to 200 m high
(Fig. 5b).

Slope failure
features can be deﬁned by faulted blocks (about 200–250 m
thick) in downslope continuity to upslope unfailed layers that
pass laterally to sea-bed structural uplifts (Fig. 5a).

Typical
headwall features are developed along isolated segments of sea-
ﬂoor uplift where the downslide movement of detached faulted–
rotated blocks (c. 200–250 m thick) can leave behind erosional

its exhibiting a set

blocks are replaced 2–5 km downslope by mass-transport depos-

Headwall scarps are deﬁned by discontinuous and
sinuous traces of thrust faults for distances over tens of kilo-
metres.

Earlier mass-
transport deposits are represented by slide deposits that glided
along deeper detachment surfaces (unit c in Fig.

Extensional faults present a similar
seaward structural zonation, with inactive normal faults tending
to be buried under the mid-shelf and active normal faults being
located on the outer shelf and upper slope (Figs 1 and 3a, b).

In
addition, portions of the palaeo fold-and-thrust belt located just
seaward of the modern shelf-slope break are taken into extension
by active normal faults, which are characterized by thick growth
sections (Fig. 3a and b).

head:
the structural and deposi-
tional systems

provenance.sentence:
This structural zonation is similar to that
observed in the Niger Delta, where the structural and deposi-
tional systems have migrated basinwards as a consequence of the
delta progradation (e.g. Damuth, 1994; Cohen & McClay 1996;
Hooper et al. 2002).

Subsequently, but still before
the Amazon Fan started to be formed, continuous sediment
deposition led to further syndepositional compression, fault
steepening and reactivation of thrust faults, causing the entire
sedimentary pile to thicken, and to drape folding of the overlying
syntectonic layer as a result of shearing stresses exerted along
two de´collement levels (the intermediate and the upper de´colle-
ment surfaces) (Fig. 6b).

Enhanced sedimentary
loading in this compartment caused further shortening and the
syn-fan reactivation of existing gravitational thrust sheets that
propagated upward; as a consequence, faulting of entire sedimen-
tary sequences occurred over large areas, forming the wide and
mostly active fold-and-thrust belts that characterize the NW
Compartment (Fig. 6c).

Adjacent
to compressional structures of the SE Compartment, slope failure
features are deﬁned by slide or rotated blocks that detach from
fold limbs caused by the sea-ﬂoor structural uplift.

sediment slides forming units

mass-transport deposits are dominated by folded and compressed

faults; basinward, they are followed by seismically homogeneous,

units), resulting in units as thick as 150–250 m (Fig.

None the less, the results discussed
above introduce new elements that allow, for the ﬁrst time, a
direct link to be established between gravitational processes that
operate at distinct spatial and temporal scales: gravity tectonics
induces regional compressional movement that forms fold-and-
thrust belts involving the entire marine sequence of the basin;
folding and thrust faulting creates sea-ﬂoor relief that triggers
mass-transport deposits.

the second method, we use wavelet transforms to identify
seismic trace singularities in each geologically oriented seg-
ment, and then we build the seismic facies map using the
clustering of the SOM.

some modern seismic facies analysis
techniques

provenance.sentence:
In this paper, we ﬁrst review some modern seismic facies analysis
techniques.

In this context, we show that the
continuous wavelet transforms CWTs and the discrete wavelet
transform DWT without time decimation can be applied to detect
singularities Shensa, 1992. We use the concepts of wavelet trans-
form modulus maxima WTMM; the lines that link the WTMMs
are called wavelet transform modulus maxima lines WTMMLs.
Then, we perform the analysis along the WTMML amplitudes,
which is called wavelet transform modulus maxima line amplitude
WTMMLA, to characterize the seismic trace singularities.

Because the
SOM can be interpreted as a mapping of the input n-dimensional
space into a 2D grid that preserves the original topological structure,
and because seismic data measures the changes in geology, SOM
preserves the topological relation of the underlying geology.
